Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of DACC-Coated vs. Alginate Dressings for Pilonidal Sinus Wound Healing

Trial_Design.evidence: A total of 246 patients undergoing pilonidal sinus surgery were randomised

Participants.evidence: This multicentre, open-label randomised controlled trial was conducted in four French hospitals

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either DACC-coated or alginate dressings postoperatively

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of dialkylcarbamoyl chloride (DACC)-coated dressings compared to alginate dressings in wound healing.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the proportion of wounds healed at 75 days.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via telephone.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible for patients or clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 246 patients undergoing pilonidal sinus surgery were randomised

Number_Analysed.evidence: In per-protocol analysis, 78 of 103 patients (75.7%) in the DACC group and 58 of 97 (60%) in the alginate group

Harms.evidence: Adverse events in the alginate group included severe pain, hyperglycaemia, pregnancy, and hyperalgic inflammatory granulation.
